title: Honey Birdette boss slams clams she is trying to 'sexualise' breast cancer with campaign
text:
Controversial Australian lingerie label Honey Birdette has hit back at critics who claim it was trying to sexualise breast cancer with its newest campaign.

The label has been accused of sexualising breast cancer and 'pinkwashing', after many claimed the 'sexy' ad was soft porn.

Managing Director Eloise Monaghan hit back at the claims saying they were 'ridiculous' and offensive to women in 2019.

She stands behind her belief the woman in the images is not sexually objectified.

'She is a model that is empowered by the product that she is wearing and that we sell in-store,' she told 10 Daily.

'In order to sell it (like any other retailer), we need to show it.'

The campaign depicted a female model wearing the brand's 'Whitney' lingerie, including pink stockings.

As Honey Birdette is a corporate partner with breast cancer charity McGrath Foundation, they chose to donate the proceeds from the pink stockings to charity.

'Our aim? To raise $30,000 for breast cancer with the Whitney pink stockings,' the advertisement said alongside the McGrath Foundation logo.

In just five days the lingerie retailer managed to donate $30,000 to charity.

However, they have since been told to remove the promotional content that had the McGrath Foundation branded on it.

Managing Director Eloise Monaghan hit back at the claims saying they were 'ridiculous' and offensive to women in 2019

The controversial move came after feminist campaign group Collective Shout accused the company of 'pinkwashing'.

The campaign group wrote a letter to the McGrath Foundation which expressed concern about the images and accused the retailer of using 'pornified portrayals of women'.

'Pairing a breast cancer charity with the sexual objectification of women is a classic example of 'pinkwashing' - a term used to describe companies that exploit breast cancer charities for profit and image enhancement,' Collective Shout wrote.

A spokeswoman for the McGrath Foundation said the images have since been taken down from the campaign.
